instruction: Can functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) be considered a superior method compared to traditional techniques for identifying functional alterations in the prefrontal cortex (PFC) of chronic pain patients?
Output: Yes. Based on the information provided in the related study, functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) can be considered a superior method compared to traditional techniques for identifying functional alterations in the prefrontal cortex (PFC) of chronic pain patients. The related study states that no studies have used a wearable, low-cost neuroimaging tool capable of performing fNIRS to explore the functional alterations of the PFC and achieve a clinical diagnosis of chronic pain. In this case-control study, fNIRS was used to measure the pain characteristics of chronic pain patients and healthy controls. The study found significantly weaker functional connectivity (FC), higher small-worldness properties of FC, and increased spontaneous brain activity within the PFC of chronic pain patients. Additionally, the resting-state fNIRS measurements exhibited excellent performance in identifying chronic pain patients using machine learning algorithms. Therefore, the use of fNIRS and machine learning techniques opens a new avenue for the diagnosis of chronic musculoskeletal pain, suggesting that fNIRS is a superior method compared to traditional techniques for identifying functional alterations in the PFC of chronic pain patients.
